name: California Chardonnay
description: California Chardonnay typically offers ripe tropical fruit flavors, creamy texture, and noticeable oak from barrel aging. Produced in regions like Napa and Sonoma counties, it's known for its bold, rich style influenced by California's warm climate.
description2: Examples of this grape that see oak treatment will have the buttery and creamy aromas and flavors often associated with California Chardonnay.

name: California Viognier
description: California Viognier typically offers very ripe tropical fruit flavors, high-tone floral aromas, and noticeable oak from barrel aging. Produced in regions like the    Central Coast and Sonoma County, it's known for its bold, aromatic style influenced by California's warm climate.
description2: If this wine sees oak treatment, it will have the buttery and creamy aromas and flavors often associated with California Chardonnay.

name: White Burgundy (Chardonnay)
description: White Burgundy, made from Chardonnay grapes in France's Burgundy region, features notes of citrus, green apple, and a distinct minerality. These wines often reflect a cooler climate with refined acidity and complex structure, especially in areas like Chablis or Meursault.
description2: These wines can have some buttery and creamy notes, as they do often see oak treatment. They tend to be slightly lighter and noticeably drier than California Chardonnay.

name: White Bordeaux (blend)
description: White Bordeaux is a blend often made with Sauvignon Blanc and Semillon, offering grapefruit, herbs, and a touch of oak.
description2: These wines hail from regions like Pessac-Léognan and Graves and balance acidity with richness. These wines can be extremely aromatic, and are usually an acquired taste.

name: Sancerre (Sauvignon Blanc)
description: Sancerre is a Sauvignon Blanc from the Loire Valley in France known for its zesty acidity, grassy notes, and flinty minerality.
description2: The region's limestone soils contribute to its crisp, refreshing character, and are best suited for those who enjoy a lighter, unoaked style of white wine.

name: Australian Chardonnay
description: Australian Chardonnay ranges from lean and mineral in regions like Margaret River to rich and oaky in places like the Hunter Valley.
description2: Common flavors include peach, melon, and vanilla with a warm-climate ripeness.

name: California Sauvignon Blanc
description: California Sauvignon Blanc is vibrant and fruit-forward with flavors of lime, grapefruit, and sometimes tropical notes.
description2: Produced throughout California, especially in Napa and Sonoma, it often exhibits a zippy, refreshing acidity.

name: New Zealand Sauvignon Blanc
description: New Zealand Sauvignon Blanc, particularly from Marlborough, bursts with aromas of passionfruit, gooseberry, and citrus zest.
description2: It's celebrated for its sharp acidity and bold, aromatic character shaped by the cool maritime climate.

name: Oregon Pinot Gris
description: Please note: this offering is slightly different than Pinot Grigio from Italy, stylistically speaking.
description2: Oregon Pinot Gris offers flavors of pear, apple, and citrus with a creamy or slightly spicy finish. This areas cooler climate helps retain the grape's natural acidity, producing fresh and food-friendly wines.

name: German Riesling
description: German Riesling is renowned for its balance of sweetness and acidity, often featuring notes of green apple, lime, and petrol in aged examples.
description2: Grown along the Mosel and Rhine rivers, these wines reflect the steep slate vineyards and cool climate. While many German rieslings are sweet, the country produces many dry examples of the grape, and they are becoming more popular and have a wider distribution now.

name: Alsatian Riesling
description: Hailing from France’s Alsace region, where the Vosges Mountains create a dry, sunny climate ideal for producing intensely aromatic white wines.
description2: Known for its purity and precision, Alsatian Riesling often exhibits notes of lime, green apple, and flint, with age bringing out petrol nuances and layered complexity. These wines come in a range of styles, but are usually slightly off-dry.

name: Argentinian Torrontés
description: Argentinian Torrontes is highly aromatic with floral notes of jasmine, rose petal, and flavors of stone fruit.
description2: Grown mainly in the high-altitude vineyards of Salta, it's crisp, dry, and refreshing despite its perfumed nose.

name: New Zealand Chardonnay
description: New Zealand Chardonnay typically exhibits fresh citrus and stone fruit flavors, with restrained oak and vibrant acidity.
description2: Regions like Hawke's Bay and Marlborough produce styles that balance fruitiness with minerality.

name: Vouvray (Chenin Blanc)
description: Vouvray is a Chenin Blanc from the Loire Valley offering flavors of quince, apple, and honey, often with a waxy texture.
description2: It can be dry, off-dry, or sparkling, depending on the producer and vintage.

name: White Rioja (blend)
description: White Rioja (Rioja Blanca) is produced primarily from the Viura grape (aka Macabeo), and often blended with Malvasía or Garnacha Blanca.
description2: Styles range from fresh and citrusy young wines to richly textured, oak-aged versions with flavors of baked apple, nuts, vanilla, and a distinct oxidative character when aged traditionally.

name: South African Chenin Blanc
description: South African Chenin Blanc, aka Steen, showcases flavors of yellow apple, honey, and sometimes tropical fruit.
description2: Grown primarily in the Western Cape, it can range from fresh and crisp to rich and barrel-aged.

name: Muscadet (Loire Valley)
description: Muscadet from the Loire Valley is made from the Melon de Bourgogne grape and is known for its light body, briny minerality, and citrusy freshness.
description2: It pairs perfectly with shellfish and reflects the maritime climate of the Pays Nantais region well.

name: Condrieu (Viognier)
description: Condrieu is a Viognier-based wine from the Rhône Valley, featuring lush flavors of apricot, peach, and floral notes with a full, oily texture.
description2: It's an expressive white grape, made in a range of styles, and is usually rich on the palate and highly aromatic.

name: Rueda (Verdejo)
description: Rueda is a Spanish wine region in Castilla y León, best known for its crisp, aromatic white wines made primarily from the native Verdejo grape, which thrives in the region’s high-altitude, continental climate.
description2: These wines are typically fresh and zesty with notes of lime, fennel, and bitter almond, often showing a slight herbaceous edge and excellent value for everyday enjoyment.

name: Vermentino
description: Vermentino is a Mediterranean white grape grown extensively in coastal regions of Italy, especially Sardinia, Liguria, and Tuscany’s Maremma.
description2: It yields vibrant, saline-driven wines with notes of citrus, green herbs, and almond, often carrying a subtle bitterness and refreshing minerality that reflect its seaside terroir.

name: Aligoté
description: Aligoté is a lesser-known white grape from Burgundy, traditionally grown in cooler sites and overshadowed by Chardonnay, producing lively, high-acid wines.
description2: Its flavor profile typically includes green apple, citrus, and subtle herbal notes, with some modern examples showing more texture and finesse.

name: Châteauneuf-du-Pape (white blend)
description: Châteauneuf-du-Pape white blends include grapes like Grenache Blanc, Roussanne, and Clairette, yielding full-bodied wines with notes of stone fruit, herbs, and honey.
description2: These Rhône Valley whites are rich, textural, and age-worthy, and are great for chardonnay drinkers and those wanting white wine with heavier dishes.

name: Willamette Valley Pinot Noir
description: Willamette Valley Pinot Noir is known for its elegance, red fruit flavors, and earthy undertones.
description2: Oregon's cool climate and volcanic soils help produce balanced wines with finesse and complexity. These wines are some of the best examples of Pinot Noir produced in America.

name: California  Pinot Noir
description: California Pinot Noir offers ripe red fruit and cola flavors with varying levels of oak and spice.
description2: Grown in coastal regions like Russian River Valley, Sonoma Coast and Santa Barbara, it tends to be more fruit-forward than examples found in Oregon and in Burgundy, France.

name: Red Burgundy (Pinot Noir)
description: Red Burgundy, made from Pinot Noir, comes from France's Cote d'Or and shows flavors of tart cherry, mushroom, and forest floor.
description2: The cooler climate and limestone soils give it a refined, earthy structure and aging potential. Red burgundy is the benchmark for great Pinot Noir, and the villages that are off the beaten path are best for value and quality to price point.

name: New Zealand Pinot Noir
description: New Zealand Pinot Noir, particularly from Central Otago and Martinborough, offers red fruit flavors with herbal and spice notes.
description2: The wines have bright acidity and a smooth texture, shaped by a cool, maritime climate. These wines can be a great find, and are highly recommended for Pinor Noir lovers to try.

name: Loire Valley Cabernet Franc (Chinon)
description: Loire Valley Cabernet Franc, especially from Chinon, features notes of red currant, bell pepper, and earthy minerality.
description2: It's lighter in body and tannin, with vibrant acidity and a savory profile.

name: German Pinot Noir (Spätburgunder)
description: German Pinot Noir, or Spätburgunder, is lighter in color with flavors of cherry, cranberry, and subtle earthy spice.
description2: This is one of those wines that you have to try if you like lighter, earthy red wines. Some of the best examples rise to the level of premier cru Burgundy.

name: California Syrah
description: California Syrah offers bold flavors of blackberry, black pepper, and smoky oak with a rich, full-bodied mouthfeel.
description2: Warmer regions like Paso robles produce a more robust style, while those from the Sonoma Coast can be slightly lighter bodied.

name: Red Bordeaux (blend)
description: Red Bordeaux blends combine Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon, and other varietals to create structured, age-worthy wines with flavors of blackcurrant, plum, and graphite.
description2: Not all Red Bordeaux's are expensive, and there are many examples of high-quality reds from here that are attractive in price. Don't be shocked to see many offerings well over $1000!

name: California Cabernet Sauvignon
description: California Cabernet Sauvignon is known for its bold structure, ripe blackberry and cassis flavors, and firm tannins.
description2: Regions like Napa Valley produce powerful, age-worthy versions with oak and spice. These wines are less dry than their Bordeaux counterparts. Areas in Sonoma County produce a slightly lighter version, with a lower pricetag than Napa Valley.

name: California Merlot
description: California Merlot delivers smooth tannins with flavors of ripe plum, black cherry, and cocoa.
description2: It's a softer red grown widely in Napa and Sonoma, offering approachability and medium body.

name: California Zinfandel
description: California Zinfandel is a bold red wine with jammy blackberry fruit, spice, and sometimes a touch of sweetness.
description2: It thrives in regions like Lodi and Sonoma, often producing high-alcohol, fruit-driven wines.

name: Australian Shiraz
description: Australian Shiraz is a full-bodied red with intense blackberry, pepper, and dark chocolate flavors.
description2: Grown extensively in Barossa Valley and McLaren Vale, it's known for its bold character and aging potential.

name: Châteauneuf-du-Pape (red blend)
description: Châteauneuf-du-Pape red blends are Grenache-based wines from the southern Rhône Valley with ripe red fruit, herbs, and spice.
description2: These wines can be powerful, very complex, and are often blended with up to a dozen different grape varietals.

name: Australian Cabernet Sauvignon
description: Australian Cabernet Sauvignon typically offers notes of blackcurrant, mint, and eucalyptus with firm tannins.
description2: It's especially prominent in Coonawarra and Margaret River, where cooler climates enhance its structure.

name: Argentinian Cabernet Sauvignon
description: Argentinian Cabernet Sauvignon displays dark fruit flavors like black cherry and plum with notes of tobacco and spice.
description2: Grown in Mendoza at high altitudes, the wines have freshness and concentration.

name: Argentinian Malbec
description: Argentinian Malbec is known for its deep color, rich blackberry and plum flavors, and smooth, velvety tannins.
description2: Mendoza's high-altitude vineyards provide the intensity and balance that define its style.

name: Chilean Merlot
description: Chilean Merlot is a medium-bodied red with flavors of red berries, plum, and subtle herbal notes.
description2: Chile's Central Valley provides a consistent climate for producing soft, approachable wines.

name: Chilean Cabernet Sauvignon
description: Chilean Cabernet Sauvignon features ripe cassis, green pepper, and a touch of vanilla oak.
description2: Grown in Maipo and Colchagua Valleys, it's known for its structure and value.

name: Washington State Syrah
description: Washington State Syrah combines bold dark fruit with pepper, smoke, and earthy complexity.
description2: Grown in Columbia Valley and Walla Walla, it balances ripeness with a cool-climate edge.

name: Washington State Merlot
description: Washington State Merlot shows rich plum and black cherry flavors with medium tannins and subtle oak.
description2: It thrives in eastern Washington's dry, sunny vineyards and often rivals more expensive Merlot from California.

name: Washington State Cabernet Sauvignon
description: Washington State Cabernet Sauvignon is structured and intense, offering flavors of blackcurrant, cocoa, and herbs.
description2: Known for its balance of fruit and acidity, it is grown widely in Columbia Valley. Slightly dryer than Napa Valley examples.

name: California Cabernet Sauvignon
description: California Cabernet Sauvignon is rich and full-bodied with flavors of blackcurrant, cedar, and toasted oak.
description2: Napa Valley versions are especially known for their power, depth, and long aging potential.

name: Chianti Classico (Sangiovese)
description: Chianti Classico is a wine region in Tuscany, Italy, where Sangiovese is the dominant grape.
description2: Expect bright acidity, firm tannins, and flavors of sour cherry, dried herbs, and earthy spice.

name: Brunello di Montalcino (Sangiovese)
description: Brunello di Montalcino comes from southern Tuscany, and is made from a local variant of the Sangiovese grape.
description2: It produces powerful, age-worthy reds with deep flavors of dark cherry, leather, tobacco, and dried herbs.

name: Barolo (Nebbiolo)
description: Barolo is a prestigious red wine from Piedmont in northwestern Italy, made exclusively from the Nebbiolo grape.
description2: Known for its firm tannins, high acidity, and complex aromas of rose, tar, cherry, and truffle.

name: Rioja (Tempranillo)
description: Spanish Tempranillo from Rioja offers flavors of dried red fruit, tobacco, and spice, often with oak influence.
description2: Rioja wines range from fresh and fruity to deeply aged Gran Reservas with complex character.

name: Super Tuscan (blend)
description: Super Tuscans are bold red blends from Tuscany that often include Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot, and Sangiovese.
description2: They defy traditional Italian DOC rules to create rich, polished wines with international appeal.

name: South African Red Blend
description: South African Red Blends commonly feature Bordeaux varietals with a mix of ripe dark fruit, earthy spice, and firm structure.
description2: These wines reflect the country's diverse terroirs and old-meets-new-world style.

name: South African Pinotage
description: South African Pinotage is a uniquely South African grape known for smoky, brambly flavors of dark fruit, coffee, and earth.
description2: It's a cross between Pinot Noir and Cinsault, producing bold, rustic reds grown mainly in the Western Cape.

name: Beaujolais (Gamay from Burgundy)
description: Beaujolais is a vibrant red wine from the southern part of Burgundy in eastern France, made primarily from the Gamay grape.
description2: Known for its light body, low tannins, and bright flavors of red berries, violets, and subtle spice, it offers a fresh and approachable profile often enjoyed slightly chilled.
